explanation_composer.regulatory_rule_cue:
Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) compliance; applies to cargo vessels navigating near major Danish shipping lanes; spatial anchor: EK R 12, EK R 11, and EK R 19
Operational Protocol Rationale: Cargo vessels in this region typically follow straight, predefined routes as part of established traffic separation schemes designed to streamline maritime flow and reduce collision risk. The vessel’s stable speed, minimal heading variation, and consistent course over ground align with autopilot-assisted transit along a fixed corridor. This behavior is characteristic of non-hazardous cargo ships of moderate size ([100, 150) m length, [20, 25) m width) operating under engine power in open coastal waters. Alternative behaviors involving curved trajectories or variable speeds are less likely here, as they are typically associated with maneuvering near ports or in congested zones, which is not the case in this segment. Given the proximity to structured shipping lanes and the kinematic consistency of the track, linear progression via time-proportional interpolation accurately reflects expected vessel motion.
